channel.title: Physiological-Sensing on Accessible IoT
channel.description: Recent content in Physiological-Sensing on Accessible IoT

item.title: A Multimodal Wearable Sensing System for Vocal Muscle Biofeedback in Singing Pitch Training
item.description: This paper presents a multimodal wearable sensing system designed to provide vocal muscle biofeedback during singing pitch training. The system helps users develop better control over their vocal muscles through real-time physiological feedback.

item.title: Biosensing, Enhanced Senses and Experience Design for Augmented Humans
item.description: This workshop paper explores the intersection of biosensing, enhanced senses, and experience design for augmented humans. It brings together researchers and practitioners to discuss how physiological sensing can create novel human augmentation experiences.

item.title: Conscious or Unconscious Meditation? Haptic Interaction Design in Meditation Augmentation Using Physiological Sensing
item.description: This paper explores haptic interaction design for meditation augmentation, examining how physiological sensing can guide both conscious and unconscious meditation practices. The work investigates how different haptic feedback patterns can enhance meditative states.

item.title: Exploring Singing Breath: Physiological Insights and Directions for Breath-Aware Augmentation in Mixed Reality Design
item.description: This paper explores the physiological aspects of singing breath control and proposes design directions for breath-aware augmentation in mixed reality. The work provides insights into respiratory patterns during singing and how they can be leveraged for immersive training experiences.

item.title: Introduction of the VCSD Dataset: A Vocal Cords Dataset Using EMG and Ultrasonography for Singing Pitch Skill Recognition
item.description: This paper introduces VCSD (Vocal Cords for Singing Dataset), a novel dataset combining EMG and ultrasonography data for singing pitch skill recognition. The dataset provides a valuable resource for researchers working on vocal training systems and physiological sensing.

item.title: A Novel Sensing Method and Its Empirical Study for Vocal Technique Analysis of Singing Pitch Control: Combining Surface EMG with Ultrasonography
item.description: This paper introduces a novel sensing method that combines surface EMG with ultrasonography to analyze vocal techniques during singing pitch control. The multimodal approach provides deeper insights into the physiological mechanisms of singing and opens new possibilities for vocal training systems.

item.title: Affective Umbrella--A Wearable System to Visualize Heart and Electrodermal Activity, towards Emotion Regulation through Somaesthetic Appreciation
item.description: The Affective Umbrella is a wearable system that visualizes heart and electrodermal activity in real-time. The work explores how somaesthetic appreciation of one’s own physiological signals can support emotion regulation and self-awareness.

item.title: Ethereal Phenomena-Interactive Art, Meditation, and Breathing Biofeedback: From Mind and Body Wellness Towards Self-Transcendence
item.description: This extended work on Ethereal Phenomena presents an interactive art installation that uses breathing biofeedback to facilitate meditation and self-transcendence. The system bridges mind-body wellness practices with technological augmentation through real-time physiological sensing and visualization.

item.title: Ethereal Phenomena
item.description: Ethereal Phenomena is an interactive art installation that explores the connection between meditation, breathing patterns, and visual representation. The work uses biofeedback to create immersive experiences that visualize physiological states.

item.title: Affective Umbrella--Towards a Novel Sensor Integrated Multimedia Platform Using Electrodermal and Heart Activity in an Umbrella Handle
item.description: This paper introduces the Affective Umbrella, a novel platform that integrates electrodermal and heart activity sensors into an umbrella handle. The system explores unobtrusive physiological monitoring in everyday situations, turning a common object into a wearable sensing device.
